questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 30-year-old male who underwent appendectomy 7 hours ago and is currently experiencing auditory hallucinations and confusion about the source of the voices? The patient maintains orientation, and his vital signs are stable. Upon inquiry, his wife reveals that he occasionally consumes alcohol.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Alcoholic hallucinosis.

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is Alcoholic Hallucinosis, given the patient’s history of alcohol consumption, auditory hallucinations, preserved orientation, stable vital signs, and recent surgical stress.
  • Alcoholic hallucinosis is a complication of chronic alcohol use, characterised by the presence of hallucinations (usually auditory) during or shortly after heavy alcohol use or withdrawal.

Incorrect Options:

Delirium tremens (Option A). A more severe withdrawal syndrome known as delirium tremens can affect alcohol users. Tremors, agitation, confusion, and hallucinations are some of its symptoms. Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that must be treated right away. Minor liquor withdrawal is described by the quake, nervousness, queasiness, spewing, and sleep deprivation. Significant liquor withdrawal signs and side effects incorporate visual mind flights and hearable pipedreams, entire body quake, heaving, diaphoresis, and hypertension (hypertension).

A/c transient psychotic disorder (Option B). Psychological stress can lead to the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms in Acute and Transient Psychotic Disorder (ATPD). In this, episodes are present moments, enduring from days to 90 days, trailed by complete abatement. Delusions, hallucinations, and mood swings are their hallmarks. Most of the time, transient psychotic disorder goes away on its own after a few weeks or a month.

Delirium (Option C). Delirium is a mental state in which you can't think clearly or remember anything, are lost, and are confused. There are many things that can cause delirium, such as an infection, taking medication, or going through a medical procedure. It usually appears out of nowhere. It is frequently brief and treatable.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the hospital with auditory hallucinations and inability to recognize his own family members. He reports his last alcohol intake was 48 hours ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with auditory hallucinations and confusion (inability to recognize family members) occurring 48 hours after his last alcohol intake. This strongly suggests delirium tremens (DTs), a severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome that typically occurs 48–96 hours after stopping alcohol. DTs are characterized by altered mental status (confusion, disorientation), hallucinations, autonomic instability (tachycardia, hypertension, fever), and severe agitation.

 

Alcohol Withdrawal- Clinical features

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Minor withdrawal

• Mild anxiety

• Tremulousness

• Nausea

• Headache

• Palpitations

6-12 hours

Alcoholic hallucinosis (Option B)

• Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations

• Intact orientation

• Normal vital signs

12-24 hours

Withdrawal seizures

• Generalized tonic-clonic seizures

• Usually brief and self-limited

• Also known as rum fits

24-48 hours

Delirium tremens

• Severe agitation

• Confusion and disorientation

• Hallucinations (often visual)

• Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)

• Profound sweating

• Tremors

• Insomnia

48-96 hours


 

Other Options:

 

Alcohol-induced psychosis (Option C): This condition refers to persistent psychotic symptoms (hallucinations, delusions) due to chronic alcohol use, rather than withdrawal. The key difference is that alcohol-induced psychosis is not associated with autonomic instability or withdrawal timing.


Schizophrenia (Option D) is a chronic psychiatric disorder with persistent hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thought processes. However, the sudden onset following alcohol cessation makes an alcohol-related withdrawal syndrome far more likely.

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lorazepam + thiamine

  • The patient exhibits symptoms of alcohol withdrawal with possible thiamine deficiency.
  • Lorazepam, a short-acting benzodiazepine, is used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms such as agitation and hallucinations.
  • Thiamine supplementation is essential to prevent or treat Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, a common complication of chronic alcoholism due to Vitamin B1 deficiency.
  • This deficiency can lead to memory gaps and confabulation, where patients unintentionally create false stories to fill those gaps.
  • Chronic alcohol use also impairs thiamine absorption, necessitating its replacement in these patients.

Haloperidol (Options A and D) is indicated only when the symptoms and agitation are severe to control high doses of Benzodiazepines, and thiamine may not suffice. In those cases, we can add antipsychotics such as Olanzapine or Haloperidol.

Lorazepam (Option B) Here, the patient also exhibits symptoms of thiamine deficiency, so Lorazepam alone does not suffice. Thiamine should be given along with lorazepam.

questions.text: What is the initial indication of alcohol withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Tremors

  • Alcohol withdrawal symptoms begin after reducing or stopping alcohol intake.
  • The earliest and most common symptom, appearing within 6-8 hours, is coarse tremors involving shaking of the hands and body.
  • Other early symptoms include gastrointestinal issues (nausea, vomiting) and autonomic hyperactivity (anxiety, sweating, tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis).

Clinical features of Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours

Delirium tremens (Option B): A severe and life-threatening symptom that develops around 72 hours after cessation of alcohol.

Seizures (Option C): Generalized tonic-clonic seizures typically occur within 12-24 hours of stopping alcohol.

Hallucinations (Option D): Alcoholic hallucinosis (commonly auditory, but visual may occur) arises within 8-12 hours after cessation and occurs with clear consciousness, without impairment.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes Korsakoff syndrome?

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
 

Explanation:

  • Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic condition caused by severe thiamine deficiency, often due to alcohol misuse, and is characterised by anterograde amnesia and loss of recent memory.
  • It often results from untreated Wernicke encephalopathy.
  • It presents with the following symptoms
    • Impaired mental syndrome - recent memory
    • Anterograde amnesia
    • Confabulation



Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (Option A)This classical triad is seen in Wernicke’s encephalopathy, an acute symptom of thiamine deficiency. It is treated with a high dose of parenteral thiamine.

 

Loss of long-term memory but intact personality (Option B) Korsakoff syndrome is characterised by severe anterograde amnesia and loss of recent memory. Some may present with retrograde amnesia. However, anterograde amnesia is more commonly observed.

 

Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall (Option D) is not seen with Korsakoff syndrome. It affects explicit memories, not implicit memory.

questions.text: What is a true statement about nicotine substitution therapy?

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption

Explanation:

  • When a patient is using nicotine gum for nicotine substitution therapy, there should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

Treatment of Nicotine addiction

Therapy

Description

Nicotine gum
  • Smokers can use 1-2 gums per hour and a maximum of 24 gums per day.
  • It releases nicotine by chewing and buccal absorption.
  • Beverages like coffee, tea, soda, and juice should not be used during gum use because they decrease absorption.
  • Poor compliance is a drawback.

Nicotine lozenges
  • Users must suck the lozenges until it is completely dissolved and must not swallow it.
  • Useful for people who smoke immediately after awakening.
  • It provides the highest level of nicotine compared to other nicotine replacement therapies.

﻿﻿Nicotine patches
  • Attached to the skin
  • Continuous delivery of nicotine and is available as 16 or 24-hour tapering preparations.
  • It has good compliance.

﻿﻿Nicotine nasal spray
  • Provides nicotine concentration in the blood similar to
    Smoking.
  • Major adverse effects are rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing

﻿﻿Nicotine inhaler
  • Nicotine absorption occurs in the upper throat, not the lungs

Non-nicotine medications
  • ﻿﻿Bupropion (an antidepressant): It has dopaminergic and adrenergic actions.
  • ﻿﻿Varenicline is a partial agonist of alpha-4 beta-2 nicotinic receptors.
    • It blocks nicotine from binding to the receptor and decreases the rewarding aspects of cigarette smoking.
    • It also stimulates the receptor and reduces withdrawal and cravings.
    • Comes with a black box warning of serious neuropsychiatric events like agitation, mood changes, and suicidal thoughts.
  • ﻿﻿Nortriptyline (Second-line drug)
  • ﻿﻿Clonidine: It decreases the sympathetic activity from locus ceruleus and is useful in controlling withdrawal symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Preferably given by gastrointestinal route (Option A). It is not true, as nicotine replacement therapy is administered through transdermal patches, lozenges, inhalers, nicotine gums, and nasal sprays.

Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death (Option B): Varenicline helps reduce craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with smoking cessation. It comes with a black box warning of serious neuropsychiatric events like agitation, mood changes, and suicidal thoughts.

Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives a 25% higher blood level than lozenges (Option D): It is not valid, as nicotine gums and lozenges are equally effective, and one does not show a 25% higher blood level.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Delirium tremens
Explanation:

  • Based on the patient's history of alcohol use and current presentation, he is most likely suffering from delirium tremens, a life-threatening condition that occurs during alcohol withdrawal.
  • It usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink and can present as:
    • Confusion,
    • Intense physical reactions
    • Visual hallucinations
    • Motor agitation
    • Disorientation
    • Paranoid delusions
    • Altered sensorium

Alcohol Withdrawal

Stage

Symptoms

Onset after last drink

Mild withdrawal
  • Mild anxiety
  • Tremulousness
  • Nausea
  • Headache
  • Palpitations

6-8 hours

Moderate (Alcoholic hallucinosis) (Option D)
  • Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations
  • Intact orientation
  • Normal vital signs

8- 12 hours

Severe (Withdrawal seizures)
  • Generalized tonic-clonic seizures
  • Usually brief and self-limited
  • Also known as rum fits

12-24 hours

Life-threatening (Delirium tremens)
  • Severe agitation
  • Confusion and disorientation
  • Hallucinations (often visual)
  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating
  • Tremors
  • Insomnia

Within 72 hours


Wernicke's encephalopathy (Option B) is a neurological disorder that occurs due to thiamine deficiency, which can occur due to alcohol abuse, nutritional habits or malabsorption.

It involves acute symptoms like problems with eye movement (nystagmus), coordination (ataxia), and confusion.

Korsakoff psychosis (Option C) results from untreated Wernicke encephalopathy. It presents with the following symptoms.

  • Impaired mental syndrome - recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment approach for a known alcoholic patient who is brought to the emergency department in a disoriented state and complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lorazepam + thiamine

Explanation:

  • The patient is showing signs of alcohol withdrawal delirium (delirium tremens), including disorientation and visual hallucinations.
  • Delirium tremens is a severe withdrawal syndrome that occurs after sudden cessation of chronic alcohol consumption.
  • It is characterised by confusion, agitation, hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity and seizures.
  • The appropriate treatment includes benzodiazepines (lorazepam) for withdrawal symptoms and thiamine to prevent neurological complications like Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.

Alcohol Withdrawal management

Alcohol Withdrawal

Treatment

Mild or Moderate Withdrawal

 
  • Treatment: Benzodiazepines (e.g., lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Short-acting (e.g., lorazepam) or long-acting (e.g., chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).
  • Carbamazepine (daily doses of 800 mg) is also effective and has minimal abuse liability.

Severe withdrawal

(Seizures)
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

Life threatening

(Delirium Tremens)

 
  • For extreme symptoms (delirium tremens or DTs), Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (e.g., 50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV).
  • Supportive care: High-calorie diet, multivitamins.
  • Thiamine: to avoid Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis. (Option B ruled out)
  • Haloperidol may be used for severe agitation but can lower the seizure threshold. (Option A and D ruled out)

Protracted Withdrawal:

Symptoms may last 2 to 6 months.
  • Acamprosate may help diminish some symptoms.
  • Cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following drug abuses can lead to the symptoms described by a 25-year-old male patient who complains of a sensation resembling insects crawling beneath his skin and has presented to the clinic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cocaine

  • Cocaine abuse can lead to formication, which is the sensation of insects crawling under the skin.
  • It is also called coke bugs or cocaine bugs
  • This is a tactile hallucination commonly seen in stimulant-induced psychosis like cocaine.
  • The drug increases dopamine levels in the brain, leading to altered sensory perceptions and pleasure.

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

Erythroxylum coca plant

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action
  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection

Signs of abuse
  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate
  • Increase in temperature
  • Rapid and deep respiration

 

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose
  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted, Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates

Cannabis (Option A) is a CNS depressant and mild hallucinogen, which primarily causes altered perceptions and mood changes, but it is not commonly associated with formication.

Heroin (Option C) is an opioid with effects that include euphoria, sedation, analgesia, and respiratory depression. It does not typically cause sensory distortions such as formication.

Alcohol (Option D) is a CNS depressant, and its withdrawal in chronic alcoholics can lead to delirium tremens, which include visual hallucinations and delirium. However, formication is not commonly associated with this.

questions.text: Jet black pigmentation of the tongue with tactile hallucinations is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cocaine

Explanation:

  • Cocaine is most commonly associated with black pigmentation of the tongue and tactile hallucinations.
  • The black pigmentation of the tongue is known as "black tongue," and it occurs due to a condition called black hairy tongue.
  • It is characterised by elongation of the filiform papillae on the tongue, which can appear black or dark brown.
  • Tactile hallucinations, also known as formication, are a common symptom of cocaine use and can involve sensations of insects crawling on or under the skin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Heroin (Option A) is an opioid drug derived from morphine. Black pigmentation of the tongue is not typically associated with heroin use. Heroin use may cause other physical symptoms, such as constricted pupils, drowsiness, and respiratory depression.

Opium (Option B) is another opioid drug derived from the poppy plant. Opium use can lead to symptoms such as sedation, euphoria, and constipation but is not associated with black pigmentation of the tongue.

Alcohol (Option C) consumption does not typically cause black pigmentation of the tongue. Excessive alcohol intake can have various effects on the body, including impaired judgment, motor coordination, and liver damage.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Delirium tremens

Explanation:

  • Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal that occurs typically 48-72 hours after the last drink. It is a medical emergency characterised by severe autonomic hyperactivity and delirium.

  • Autonomic hyperactivity (tachycardia, hypertension, fever)
  • Profound sweating

Within 72 hours

 

Korsakoff’s psychosis (Option B) or Korsakoff’s syndrome, is a chronic neuropsychiatric disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often linked to chronic alcoholism. It typically follows Wernicke’s encephalopathy and is marked by severe memory problems, including amnesia, confabulation, lack of insight, and apathy. Unlike acute conditions, it is characterized by chronic memory deficits rather than symptoms like tremors, hallucinations, disorientation, or hypertension.

Marchiafava-Bignami disease (Option D) is a rare condition in chronic alcoholics, characterized by demyelination of the corpus callosum and surrounding white matter, leading to severe neurological deficits. Symptoms include seizures, dysarthria, spasticity, and progressive cognitive impairment. Acute symptoms like disorientation, tremors, hallucinations, and hypertension are not typical, as the disease primarily presents with chronic, progressive neurological symptoms.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a 40-year-old male patient who was admitted to the ICU three days ago due to breathing difficulty and is currently experiencing restlessness and widespread tremors? The patient has reported seeing insects crawling on his bed and body and has had one seizure, which was successfully managed with lorazepam. Further investigation reveals that the patient is a chronic alcoholic.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Delirium tremens.

Explanation:

  • The patient’s symptoms, including restlessness, tremors, tactile hallucinations (seeing insects crawling), a seizure, and a history of chronic alcoholism, strongly indicate delirium tremens (DT).
  • It typically occurs 48–72 hours after cessation or reduction of alcohol use.
  • It is a severe alcohol withdrawal syndrome characterised by tremors, agitation, confusion, and hallucinations.

ICU psychosis (Option A) is a mental health condition that can develop in ICU patients due to stress, sedatives, and other medications. Symptoms include hallucinations, delusions, and agitation. Unlike ICU psychosis, delirium tremens (DTs) result from alcohol withdrawal.

Alcohol Intoxication (Option B): This diagnosis is unlikely since the patient has been sober for three days. Alcohol intoxication results from excessive alcohol consumption and presents with symptoms such as slurred speech, impaired coordination, confusion, and, in severe cases, loss of consciousness or even death. The patient's current symptoms are more consistent with alcohol withdrawal rather than intoxication.

Wernicke-Korsakoff psychosis (Option C) is a neurological disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It presents with symptoms such as confusion, memory loss, and ataxia. Wernicke's encephalopathy represents the acute phase, while Korsakoff's syndrome is the chronic stage. The disorder's main features are problems in acquiring new information or establishing new memories and in retrieving previous memories.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect?

choices.text: Cannabis causes minimal physical withdrawal symptoms
Opioid withdrawal rarely results in death
Buprenorphine is used in opioid withdrawal treatment
Flumazenil is used in the long-term treatment of alcohol dependence

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Flumazenil is used in the long-term treatment of alcohol dependence

Explanation:

  • Flumazenil is not used in the long-term treatment of alcohol dependence. It is a benzodiazepine receptor antagonist and is used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.
  • Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease characterised by an inability to control alcohol consumption despite adverse social, occupational, or health consequences. Dependence occurs only in heavy and round-the-clock drinking.
  • Management of alcohol dependence:
    • Both psychological and medical supportive measures should be provided.
    • Anti-craving drugs

Anti-craving drugs
 

Drug Name

Mechanism of Action

Notes

FDA-
approved anti-craving drugs

Disulfiram

Inhibits acetaldehyde dehydrogenase ADH

Aversive agent to be used only in highly motivated person by causing unpleasant reactions if alcohol is consumed

Naltrexone

Blocks opioid receptors

Reduces cravings and desire to drink

Acamprosate

Modulates glutamate & GABA systems

Reduces cravings and helps maintain abstinence

Not FDA-
approved (off-label use)

Baclofen

GABA agonist

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Gabapentin

& Topiramate

Modulates GABA & glutamate systems

Helps with alcohol withdrawal symptoms

Incorrect Options:

Cannabis causes minimal physical withdrawal symptoms (Option A): Cannabis withdrawal typically includes mild psychological symptoms physical withdrawal is minimal and non-life-threatening.

  • Common symptoms include:
    • Irritability
    • Anxiety
    • Disturbed sleep/dreaming
    • Depressed mood
    • Loss of appetite
    • Cannabis cravings
    • Nervousness
    • Restlessness
  • Less Common Symptoms:
    • Headaches
    • Physical tension
    • Sweating
    • Chills
    • Stomach pain
    • Tremors

Opioid withdrawal rarely results in death (Option B): Although opioid withdrawal can be extremely uncomfortable (nausea, vomiting, cramps, sweating, anxiety), it is rarely fatal, unlike alcohol or benzodiazepine withdrawal, which can be life-threatening. Opioid withdrawal symptoms include:

  • Muscle and Bone aches, Abdominal cramps
  • Diarrhoea, Lacrimation, Rhinorrhea, Sweating - resembles flu
  • Piloerection/ Gooseflesh ("Cold Turkey" Means Abstinence Syndrome)
  • Frequent yawning, Insomnia
  • Mydriasis
  • Hypertension, Tachycardia
  • Temperature Dysregulation (Hypothermia Or Hyperthermia)
  • Nausea, vomiting, and restlessness

Buprenorphine is used in opioid withdrawal treatment (Option C): Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist used in medication-assisted treatment for opioid withdrawal and maintenance therapy. It helps relieve withdrawal symptoms and cravings with a lower risk of overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following psychoactive substances is a new, rapidly acting antidepressant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ketamine

Explanation:

  • Ketamine is a new, rapidly acting antidepressant that has gained significant attention in recent years, especially for patients with treatment-resistant depression (TRD) and suicidal ideation.
  • Ketamine is a NMDA receptor antagonist.
  • MOA: Blocks NMDA receptors on GABAergic interneurons → disinhibits glutamate neurons → glutamate burst.
    • It works by increasing glutamate, synaptic plasticity, and BDNF-mediated pathways.

Incorrect Options:

﻿﻿﻿Bupropion (Option B) is a atypical antidepressant used for depression and smoking cessation. It has a standard delayed onset of antidepressant action

﻿﻿﻿Haloperidol (Option C) belongs to the class of first-generation antipsychotic medications, also known as typical antipsychotics, primarily used for schizophrenia and acute psychosis. Not used for depression.

﻿﻿﻿Cannabinoids (Option D) do not have approved (FDA approval) or evidence-based use as antidepressants and are not rapid-acting.

questions.text: Imipramine and Diphenhydramine are given together to a patient. Why is this combination considered irrational?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Both have anticholinergic action

Explanation:

  • Imipramine, a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA), and diphenhydramine, a first-generation antihistamine, both exhibit significant anticholinergic properties, hence combining these two drugs is considered irrational because their additive anticholinergic effects.
  • Effects such as drowsiness, blurred vision, dry mouth, heat intolerance, flushing, decreased sweating, difficulty urinating, abdominal cramping, constipation, irregular heartbeat, and confusion.
  • Diphenhydramine does not significantly affect serotonin. Imipramine affects serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake, but the combination does not increase serotonin syndrome risk. (Option B)
  • Imipramine may cause orthostatic hypotension due to alpha-1 blockade, but diphenhydramine generally does not cause significant hypotension.
  • While both can cause sedation, this is not the primary concern. Sedation is common but not necessarily irrational unless it causes functional impairment. Anticholinergic load is the greater clinical concern.

questions.text: The tactile hallucinations seen in cases of chronic cocaine intoxication are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Formication

  • The tactile hallucinations experienced in cases of chronic cocaine use are commonly referred to as "cocaine bugs" or formication.

Cocaine-Induced Psychotic Disorder:

  • Characterised by paranoid delusions and hallucinations.
  • Affects up to 50% of stimulant users.
  • Types of Hallucinations:
    • Auditory hallucinations are common.
    • Visual and tactile hallucinations are less common but may occur.
    • Cocaine can cause formication/ Cocaine bugs (sensation of bugs crawling under the skin).
  • Symptoms depend on dose, duration of use, and individual sensitivity to stimulants.
  • More frequent in users of intravenous cocaine or crack cocaine.
  • Psychotic symptoms are seen more in men than in women.
  • Treatment:
    • The preferred treatment is short-term use of antipsychotics like haloperidol, especially for amphetamine-induced psychosis.

Oneroid state (Option A) refers to an impaired consciousness involving dream-like experiences with vivid perceptions, hallucinations, and delusions, leading to disorientation and difficulty distinguishing reality. There are fluctuating periods of clarity and confusion, with detachment from the environment.

Dipsomania (Option B) refers to a compulsive, uncontrollable craving for alcohol, often leading to binge drinking. It is considered a form of alcohol use disorder characterised by episodes of intense desire to drink despite negative consequences.

Carphologia (Option C) refers to a medical condition characterised by the repetitive, purposeless picking at or tearing of one's clothes, bedding, or other objects, often seen in individuals with certain psychiatric or neurological conditions.

questions.text: Which drug is used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Buprenorphine:

  • Buprenorphine is used in the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Disulfiram:

  • It is not used in opioid withdrawal. It is primarily used in the treatment of alcohol dependence.

Option C – Butorphanol:

  • It is not used during the maintenance phase of opioid withdrawal.

Option D - Clonidine:

  • It is used in the detoxification phase in an opioid-addicted patient who is unwilling to be treated with opioids

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic alcoholic who began binge drinking ten days ago is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. A CT scan of his brain is normal, but his blood glucose level is 45 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IM Thiamine followed by dextrose:

  • Chronic alcoholics are often thiamine-deficient. Administering glucose before thiamine can precipitate Wernicke's encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder because glucose metabolism increases the demand for thiamine. This can lead to acute thiamine deficiency in the brain, exacerbating the condition. Therefore, giving thiamine first helps prevent this complication.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Normal saline hydration:

  • Normal saline alone does not correct hypoglycemia.

Options C and D are incorrect, as prior thiamine supplementation is necessary before glucose administration.

questions.text: A mother brings her daughter to the emergency room, reporting that she ingested an unknown substance. She presents with hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, and mydriasis. Which of the following substances is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Cocaine:

  • Cocaine acts by increasing levels of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. The symptoms described are all classic signs of cocaine intoxication.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B – Heroin and morphine:

  • It leads to respiratory depression, hypotension, bradycardia, and pinpoint pupils (miosis).

Option D - Chlorpheniramine: It is an antihistamine and is not associated with the given symptoms.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital following a road traffic accident (RTA). He presents with confusion, irritability, and tremors. The patient has a history of daily alcohol consumption. Which drug is most appropriate to prevent withdrawal symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lorazepam:

  • Lorazepam is a short-acting benzodiazepine, which is the drug of choice for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.
  • Benzodiazepines are effective in reducing the symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, including anxiety, seizures, and delirium tremens (DTs).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D have no role in treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department with diplopia and ataxia, and he was completely confused. A history of alcohol was noted. What is the initial treatment of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IV Thiamine

Explanation:

  • The given case, presenting with confusion, diplopia, and ataxia, along with a history of alcoholism, is diagnosed as Wernicke's Encephalopathy (also known as Alcoholic Encephalopathy), with intravenous thiamine being the initial treatment of choice.
  • It is an acute, potentially life-threatening neurological syndrome resulting from thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly found in chronic alcoholics.
  • The classic triad of symptoms in Wernicke's encephalopathy includes
    • Encephalopathy (confusion),
    • Oculomotor dysfunction (painful eye movements, nystagmus, ophthalmoplegia)
    • Ataxia.
  • The 6th cranial nerve (which controls lateral movement of the eye) is also involved.
  • Other eye signs may include a sluggish reaction to light and anisocoria (unequal pupillary size).
  • It may progress to Korsakoff syndrome (Korsakoff psychosis).

 

  Wernicke's Encephalopathy Korsakoff Syndrome
Onset Acute Chronic often follows Wernicke's syndrome
Key Symptoms
  • Global Confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities (nystagmus, gaze palsy)
  • Ataxia (especially gait)
  • Severe anterograde amnesia
  • Retrograde amnesia
  • Confabulation (in some cases)

Cause

Thiamine deficiency

Prolonged thiamine deficiency

Neuropathological lesions

Symmetrical and paraventricular, involving mammillary bodies, thalamus, hypothalamus, midbrain, pons, medulla, fornix, and cerebellum

Treatment

Immediate IV thiamine (Option B)

Long-term thiamine supplementation, supportive care

Prognosis

Potentially reversible with prompt treatment

Often irreversible, only about 20% recover

 

IV Lorazepam (Option A) is a benzodiazepine that is not effective for Wernicke’s encephalopathy but is the preferred treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms. It is also used to control seizures and manage status epilepticus.

IV fluid + dextrose (Option C) is also helpful in the management of Wernicke’s encephalopathy but is not the initial step of management.

Vitamin B12 (Option D) is also used in the management of Wernicke’s encephalopathy but is not the initial step of management.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a 20-year history of chronic alcohol consumption, averaging 500 ml daily, presents to the clinic with complaints of sensations of insects crawling on his skin, agitation, and irritation. He reports that his last drink was 3 days ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delirium tremens

Explanation:

  • The patient’s agitation, hallucinations (insects crawling), and history of heavy alcohol use with cessation 3 days ago suggest delirium tremens that typically occur 48-72 hours after the last drink in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

Stage of Alcohol Withdrawal

Symptoms

Onset After Last Drink

Treatment

Mild Withdrawal

Mild anxiety, tremulousness, nausea, headache, palpitations

6-8 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam). Carbamazepine (800 mg daily).

Moderate (Alcoholic Hallucinosis)

Visual, auditory, or tactile hallucinations, intact orientation, normal vital signs

8-12 hours

Benzodiazepines (lorazepam, chlordiazepoxide, diazepam).

Severe (Withdrawal Seizures)

Generalized tonic-clonic seizures, usually brief and self-limited (rum fits)

12-24 hours

Benzodiazepines (Treatment of choice).

Anticonvulsants not more beneficial.

Life-Threatening (Delirium Tremens)

Severe agitation, confusion, disorientation, visual hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity, profound sweating, tremors, insomnia

Within 72 hours

Higher doses of Benzodiazepines (50-100 mg chlordiazepoxide every 4 hours or lorazepam IV). Supportive care (high-calorie diet, multivitamins).

Haloperidol for severe agitation (caution with seizure threshold).

Protracted Withdrawal

Symptoms may last 2-6 months

-

Acamprosate is recommended for symptom relief, and cognitive and behavioural approaches are recommended.


Incorrect Options:

Alcohol intoxication (Option A) can cause disorientation and behavioural changes, but it doesn't cause diplopia or insect crawling sensation on the skin. The excitement that follows drinking is due to CNS depression.

Tolerance (Option C): An Increased amount of substance is required to produce the desired effects previously produced by lower amounts. It develops quickly (2-3 days of repeated use), lost after 4-6 days of abstinence.

Reaction due to alcohol (Option D) is an immediate response following alcohol consumption.

questions.text: A patient was taking metronidazole for diarrhoea. He attended a party where he consumed alcohol. Following this, he developed red rashes, itching all over his body, and a headache. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Disulfiram-like reaction

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of red rashes, itching, and headache after consuming alcohol while on metronidazole suggest a Disulfiram-like reaction.
  • This occurs when metronidazole interacts with alcohol, causing symptoms such as flushing, nausea, sweating, and headache, similar to the effects of disulfiram (Antabuse), which is used to discourage alcohol consumption.

 

  • When alcohol is ingested by someone taking disulfiram, it inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of acetaldehyde in the blood, which causes unpleasant symptoms.
    • Flushing
    • Headache
    • Nausea & vomiting
    • Sweating
    • Palpitations, chest pain, and dizziness
    • Dyspnea
    • Hypotension and circulatory collapse

Drugs causing disulfiram-like reaction: (Mnemonic- CGMP)

They are contraindicated in active drinkers.

  • Chlorpropamide
  • Cephalosporins (mnemonic- PMTX):
    • CefoPerazone
    • CefaMandole
    • CefoTetan
    • CefoXitin
  • Griseofulvin
  • Metronidazole
  • Procarbazine

Methanol poisoning (Option A) occurs as a result of drinking contaminated beverages with methanol and presents as drowsiness and a reduced level of consciousness. It is not associated with metronidazole.

Cheese reaction (Option C) occurs when monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) block the breakdown of tyramine from foods like aged cheese, causing a surge in norepinephrine release. This leads to symptoms such as severe headaches, palpitations, and high blood pressure. The treatment for this reaction includes phentolamine, an alpha-blocker, to help manage the symptoms.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use (24 units per day for the past 10 years) presents with seizures, altered mental status, auditory hallucinations, and secondary delusions. His last alcohol consumption was 2 days ago. What is the appropriate management for this patient?


	Diazepam
	Thiamine
	Naltrexone
	Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2

Explanation:

  • The symptoms suggest that the patient is suffering from delirium tremens, and the appropriate treatment includes benzodiazepines (diazepam) for withdrawal symptoms and thiamine to prevent neurological complications like Wernicke Encephalopathy or Korsakoff psychosis.
  • Delirium tremens is a severe withdrawal syndrome that occurs after sudden cessation of chronic alcohol consumption. It is characterized by confusion, agitation, hallucinations, autonomic hyperactivity and seizures.
  • Seizures can occur suddenly; about 1% may experience a single grand mal convulsion, typically on the second day of withdrawal.
  • Treatment of choice: Benzodiazepines.
  • Anticonvulsants are not more beneficial.

 

(Option C): Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used to treat alcohol dependence by reducing cravings, but it is not indicated in the acute withdrawal phase. It is more useful for maintaining abstinence once the patient has been stabilized and no longer requires acute management.

 

(Options A & B): Flupenthixol is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia or other psychotic disorders, not alcohol withdrawal. Although the patient has auditory hallucinations and delusions, these are likely related to alcohol withdrawal, which should be treated with benzodiazepines.

questions.text:
Which of the following is used to define dependence:

a. Strong desire to use the drug

b. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity

c. Increased tolerance

d. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - a, b, c, d

  • All of the above statements describe Dependence, which is a condition in which an individual experiences both physical and psychological symptoms due to substance use.

Type of Dependence

Definition

Behavioural Dependence

Focuses on substance-seeking behaviours and the patterns of pathological use.

Physical Dependence

Refers to the physiological effects that result from repeated episodes of substance use.

Psychological Dependence

Also called habituation, characterised by a persistent or occasional craving to avoid dysphoria.

Substance Use Disorder Criteria (DSM-5):

The criteria for diagnosing substance dependence can be grouped into four main categories:

  1. Impaired Control:
    • Using larger amounts or for longer periods than intended
    • Persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control use
    • Spending excessive time obtaining, using, or recovering from the substance
    • Experiencing intense cravings or urges to use the substance (Statement a)
  2. Social Impairment:
    • Failing to fulfil major role obligations due to substance use
    • Continuing use despite persistent social or interpersonal problems
    • Giving up important activities because of substance use (Progressive Neglect) (Statement b)
  3. Risky Use:
    • Recurrent use in physically hazardous situations
    • Continued use despite knowledge of physical or psychological problems caused or exacerbated by the substance (Persistence) (Statement d)
  4. Pharmacological Criteria:
    • Tolerance: Needing increased amounts to achieve desired effects or experiencing reduced effects with the same amount. (Statement c)
    • Withdrawal: Experiencing characteristic withdrawal symptoms or using the substance to relieve withdrawal.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol consumption is admitted to the hospital with features of confusion, vision loss and an unsteady gait. He is unable to remember the most recent incidents. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Thiamine (Vitamin B1):

  • Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine deficiency due to poor dietary intake and impaired absorption.
  • This disorder is known as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and is characterized by confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, confabulation and amnesia.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Ascorbic acid (Vitamin C): Ascorbic acid deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by weakness, joint pain, bleeding gums, and skin changes.

Option B - Retinol (Vitamin A): Retinol deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, and vision-related issues.

Option D - Folate (Vitamin B9): Folate deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects in pregnant women.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements


	Statement 1-Contemplation - A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking
	Statement 2 - Precontemplation - A person is considering starting morning walks and its benefits to their health
	Statement 3- Maintenance phase- A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then
	Statement 4-Action phase- A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs deep in his family
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Statements 1 and 3 are correct:

Transtheoretical Model of Change (also known as the Stages of Change Model)

  • It is a comprehensive model that describes an individual's journey through different stages of behavior change.

  • Developed by Prochaska and DiClemente, this model is relevant in addiction, smoking cessation, and lifestyle changes.

  • The model comprises five stages:

Precontemplation

(Statement 2 ruled out)

  • The individual is not considering a change in behaviour in the foreseeable future.

  • They may be unaware or in denial about the need for change.

Contemplation

(Statement 1)

  • The individual recognises the problem and is considering change but is not yet ready to take action.

Preparation

  • The individual is intending to take action shortly (usually within the next 30 days)

  • May have started taking small steps toward change.

Action

(Statement 4 ruled out)

  • The individual has recently made changes (within the last 6 months)

  • Actively working to maintain those changes.

Maintenance

(Statement 3)

  • The individual has sustained their behaviour change for more than 6 months

  • Working to prevent relapse.

questions.text: What is the predominant manifestation experienced with cannabis consumption?
questions.solution:
Correct Answers C - Dream-like state

  • The predominant manifestation of cannabis consumption is a dream-like state characterised by altered perception, euphoria, and detachment from reality. Cannabis primarily affects the central nervous system, inducing a state of relaxation and altered sensory experiences.

Cannabis

Aspect

Description

Composition
  • Over 400 compounds
  • Includes cannabinoids, flavonoids, and terpenoids
  • Primary psychoactive component: Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)

Forms
  • Dried plant material (marijuana)
  • Bhang (Derived from dried leaves)
  • Ganja (derived from flowering stem)
  • Hashish (concentrated resin)
  • Oils and extracts (Hash oil)
  • Edibles
  • Topical preparations

Receptors
  • CB1 and CB2 (G-protein coupled receptors- Gi subtype)

Methods of Use
  • Smoking (most common)
  • Vaporizing
  • Oral ingestion
  • Sublingual administration
  • Topical application

Clinical Features of Intoxication
  • Tachycardia
  • Conjunctival injection
  • Anxiety or euphoria
  • Slowness of time
  • Impaired cognition and motor coordination
  • Dry mouth
  • Increased appetite
  • Nystagmus
  • Postural hypotension
  • Delirium (especially at high doses)

Onset and Duration of Effects
  • Smoking: Rapid onset (minutes), duration 2-3 hours
  • Oral ingestion: Delayed onset (30-90 minutes), duration 4-12 hours

Anxiety (Option A). While some people may experience anxiety or paranoia after using cannabis, this is not the most common symptom. In fact, some strains of cannabis are known for their calming and anxiety-reducing effects.

Depressed mood (Option B). Cannabis can have mood-altering effects, but a depressed mood is not the most common symptom. In some cases, cannabis may actually improve mood and alleviate symptoms of depression.

Decreased appetite (Option D). Cannabis is known for causing "the munchies," or an increase in appetite rather than a decrease. While some strains may have more appetite-suppressing effects, this is not the most common symptom.

questions.text: What is the etiology of delirium tremens in a 48-year-old male who presents to the emergency room with symptoms of confusion and generalized body tremors, and has a known history of heavy alcohol use?

choices.text: Small does of regular consumption of alcohol

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Gradual withdrawal of alcohol:

  • Delirium tremens in an alcoholic is caused by the gradual withdrawal of alcohol. Abrupt cessation or significant reduction of alcohol intake leads to hyperexcitability of the brain, resulting in the manifestation of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute infection: Acute infection is not the cause of delirium tremens in an alcoholic. Delirium tremens occurs due to alcohol withdrawal.

Option B - Fatty liver: Fatty liver is not the direct cause of delirium tremens. It is a consequence of chronic alcohol abuse but does not directly lead to delirium tremens.

Option D - Small doses of regular consumption of alcohol: Small doses of regular alcohol consumption are not the cause of delirium tremens. It occurs with the withdrawal of alcohol rather than regular consumption.

questions.text: Which drug listed below is utilized as an agent for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Varenicline:

  • Varenicline is a medication used as an antismoking agent. It works by targeting nicotine receptors in the brain, reducing the pleasurable effects of smoking and decreasing nicotine withdrawal symptoms. Varenicline is commonly prescribed to individuals who want to quit smoking or tobacco use.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Busulfan: Busulfan is not used as an antismoking agent. It is a chemotherapy medication primarily used in the treatment of certain types of cancer, such as leukemia.

Option B - Acamprosate: Acamprosate is a medication used in the treatment of alcohol dependence. It helps individuals who have quit drinking alcohol to maintain abstinence by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

Option D - Gabapentin: Gabapentin is primarily used as an antiepileptic medication, but it can also be prescribed for certain types of chronic pain or neuropathic conditions.

questions.text: Which drug among the options provided would assist a chronic smoker in their aim to quit smoking?
questions.solution:
Option D - Both A and C:

  • Smoking cessation drugs can be an effective tool to help individuals quit smoking. The following drugs are approved by the FDA for smoking cessation:
    • Both bupropion and varenicline are approved by the FDA for smoking cessation and have been shown to be effective in helping individuals quit smoking. They can be used alone or in combination with nicotine replacement therapy.

Option A - Bupropion: Bupropion is an antidepressant that is also used as a smoking cessation aid. It works by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms. It is taken orally and is usually started 1-2 weeks before the quit date.

Option C - Varenicline: Varenicline is a prescription medication that is specifically designed to help individuals quit smoking. It works by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms and by blocking the effects of nicotine. It is taken orally and is usually started 1 week before the quit date.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Mirtazapine: Mirtazapine is not approved by the FDA for smoking cessation and has not been shown to be effective in helping individuals quit smoking.
